data.title: The broken editor
data.statement:
Your favourite code editor broke, it can't display what you're typing anymore!
Replace the part that handles the keyboard inputs and build the output yourself!

All [[typed_keys]] can be either a <<character>>, a <<keyboard arrow>> (left / right) represented by {{<}} and {{>}} or a <<backspace>> represented by the minus sign {{-}}
{{<}} moves the editor's cursor to the left
{{>}} moves the editor's cursor to the right
{{-}} removes one character on the left side of the cursor's position (backspace behaviour)
Keep in mind that a cursor has boundaries: from the left of the first character to the right of the last one

<<Example 1:>>
You typed an extra {{L}} in <<Helllo World>> and removed it with a backspace:
`<<Input>>: Helll-o World
<<Output>>: Hello World`
<<Example 2:>>
While typing too fast, you skipped the {{e}}. You pressed left arrow twice, typed {{e}} then went back to the right and typed the rest ("o World")
`<<Input>>: Hll<<<<>>e>>o World
<<Output>>: Hello World`
Good luck!

testCases.title: Single mistake
testCases.testIn: Midnight takes hear<<<<your >>>>t and your soul
testCases.testOut: Midnight takes your heart and your soul

testCases.title: Single mistake Validator
testCases.testIn: Put your without<<<<<<<heart >>>>>>> your soul into your heart
testCases.testOut: Put your heart without your soul into your heart

testCases.title: Out of bounds Validator
testCases.testIn: <<SELECT>> COUNT(1) FROM users WHERE creation_date <= NOW()<<<<<
testCases.testOut: SELECT COUNT(1) FROM users WHERE creation_date= NOW()

data.inputDescription: <<Line 1: [[typed_keys]]>> A string representing all the pressed keys (characters/arrows/backspaces)
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1:>> The text to display in the editor's window

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Your favourite code editor broke, it can't display what you're typing anymore!
Replace the part that handles the keyboard inputs and build the output yourself!

All typed_keys can be either a character, a keyboard arrow (left / right) represented by < and > or a backspace represented by the minus sign -
< moves the editor's cursor to the left
> moves the editor's cursor to the right
- removes one character on the left side of the cursor's position (backspace behaviour)
Keep in mind that a cursor has boundaries: from the left of the first character to the right of the last one

Example 1:
You typed an extra L in Helllo World and removed it with a backspace:
Input: Helll-o World
Output: Hello World

Example 2:
While typing too fast, you skipped the e. You pressed left arrow twice, typed e then went back to the right and typed the rest ("o World")
Input: Hll<<e>>o World
Output: Hello World

Good luck!
Input
Line 1: typed_keys A string representing all the pressed keys (characters/arrows/backspaces)
Output
Line 1: The text to display in the editor's window
Constraints
1 ≤ length of typed_keys ≤ 80
Example
Input
echo "Hello World!";
Output
echo "Hello World!";
